thread.title: RIVERSIDE: Baby Tattooville inks lasting influence
thread.title_full: RIVERSIDE: Baby Tattooville inks lasting influence - Press Enterprise

author: LAURIE LUCAS
title: RIVERSIDE: Baby Tattooville inks lasting influence
text:
BY LAURIE LUCAS / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 2, 2015 5:29 p.m. RIVERSIDE: Baby Tattooville inks lasting influence Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 6 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Exhibition coordinator Allen Morton examines artwork for the show “Baby Tattooville: Fade to Black,” before hanging the pieces from 10 artists. STAN LIM , STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Related article » IF YOU GO What: ""Baby Tattooville: Fade to Black," the final exhibition of a pop surrealism show with 25 works of 10 "lowbrow" artists
Where: Riverside Art Museum, 3425 Mission Inn Ave., Riverside
When: Through Sat. Jan. 9
Admission: $5 general; $3 for students with ID and 65 and over; free for members, military with ID and under 12, first Sundays and Arts Walk.
Information: 951- 684-7111; RiversideArtMuseum.org
'BABY TATTOOVILLE' ARTISTS Anthony Ausgang: ausgangart.com
Sas Christian: saschristian.com
Olivia de Berardinis: eolivia.com
Ron English: popaganda.com
Camille Rose Garcia: camillerosegarcia.com
Bosko Hrnjak: boskoart.com/
Marion Peck: marionpeck.com
KRK Ryden: krkland.com
Mark Ryden: markryden.com
Isabel Samaras: isabelsamaras.com
In 2008, a Van Nuys book publisher anointed Riverside– hardly synonymous with avant-garde and hip –as the ideal city to showcase a collection of strange, whimsical and wacky artworks.
Strange, whimsical and wacky don’t exactly square with the image of a community that’s long prided itself on orange crate labels as art.
But this publisher, Bob Self, enamored of Riverside’s dreamlike downtown, organized a completely different kind of art show called pop surrealism.
He let loose with the installation “Baby Tattooville,” showcasing works from alternative artists at the Riverside Art Museum that exploded and shimmered with clashing, iridescent colors or odd combinations of pastels and peopled with stick figures, cartoon characters, skeletons and macabre clowns.
The exhibition has taken on a life of its own and returned every year, altering the perception of Riverside from cultural backwater to cutting-edge hub. “It became a one-of-a-kind experience that you could only get here,” said Margie Haupt, the city’s arts and cultural affairs manager.
That experience is drawing to a close. While “Baby Tattooville” may be taking its final bow, the city’s reputation as an artistic risk-taker will continue to command center stage.
The curious title, “Baby Tattooville,” which has nothing to do with infants or ink, has drilled itself into the city’s artistic soul for nearly a decade as an annual must-see event.
Self, 49, the show’s originator and producer, said his sister dreamed up the handle 13 years ago after watching his year-old daughter press on temporary tats.
Self’s last hurrah, “Baby Tattooville: Fade to Black,” which opened on Thursday, Oct. 1, showcases the expected “lowbrow” mix of disquieting, in-your-face, nostalgic and offbeat works from pioneers of alternative art. After the exhibition closes on Saturday, Jan. 9, Self’s baby will vanish for good.
Its swan song consists of 25 works– none for sale– by 10 mostly Los Angeles-based artists. They include art rock stars, Mark Ryden and his wife, Marion Peck, whose macabre, quietly creepy works are collected by A-list celebrities. Avant-garde pop star Lady Gaga told the press that Ryden inspired the meat dress she wore several years ago and Katy Perry has tweeted about his imagery.
OUTSIDE THE MAINSTREAM “Bob Self has a specific vision,” said Haupt.
By embracing it, the community has helped raise this outsider style to mainstream and instrumental in shifting public opinion, said Patrick Brien, executive director of the Riverside Arts Council.
A decade ago, the city never would have never sponsored the mural which Riverside street artists Jeff Soto and Maxx242 spray-painted this spring on the outside wall of Pixels Bar, Brien said. “ Now it's a big calling card for us as the City of Arts and Innovation.”
“Baby Tattooville” has captivated an eclectic audience, some of whom popped into the Riverside Art Museum for the first time in their lives, said museum trustee and longtime arts supporter Sperry MacNaughton.
Since it landed in the community eight years ago as Self’s love letter to Riverside, “Baby Tattooville” has drawn some of the museum’s biggest and youngest crowds because of the show’s “strange, fun and magnificent” appeal, said Drew Oberjuerge, executive director. “It really put Riverside on the map.”
